title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves funds for outlying areas, Bureau of Indian Education, and administration. States receive awards based on a percentage of remaining funds. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on the population of individuals aged 5 through 17 and the State's total population compared to other States. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds to other States using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. (a) Application.--Within 30 days of this Act's enactment, a State's chief executive must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this title, including assurances to maintain State support for education at or above 2011 levels for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. 
(b) Letter.--A chief executive of a State not seeking a grant must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment. The Act requires a State's chief executive to submit a letter to the Secretary if they do not wish to receive a grant under this title. The Secretary has the authority to waive certain requirements for a State under exceptional circumstances or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education, distributed based on enrollment ratios. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. A portion of the funds is reserved for State-funded early learning programs. The State must make subgrants available to local educational agencies within 100 days of receiving the grant. Grant funds cannot be used for certain purposes. A State receiving a grant under this title is prohibited from using the funds to establish, restore, or supplement a rainy-day fund, supplant State funds to reduce debt, or supplant State funds to retire debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants must be used for retaining, recalling, or hiring employees for educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. State-funded early learning programs must use funds for early childhood educators. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. Reporting requirements. SEC. 107. REPORTING.

States receiving grants must report on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014.

SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS.

Defines terms like "State" and "State-funded early learning program."

SEC. 109. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION

SEC. 201. PURPOSE.

    This title aims to provide funding to States and localities to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters.

SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM. SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain fire department resources. Waivers may be granted for certain requirements. Additionally, $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM.

The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers. $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
